Award.AwardTitle: Remote Infrastructure Monitoring Assessment via Multispectral Imaging of Surface Coatings

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Our country's aging and deteriorating infrastructure creates the need for transformative science and technology that can assist in novel management and maintenance approaches. This award supports fundamental research on monitoring, measurement, analysis and computations in support of system diagnostics, applicable to a civil infrastructure. Examples include bridges, railroads, masonry buildings, networks of pipelines, powerlines, dams and more. This award investigates multispectral imaging through novel coatings that act as selectively responsive sensing units when deposited on actual structural components and monitored by appropriate imaging devices. The results of this award could be used to implement unprecedented structural health monitoring procedures which combined with the use of unmanned aerial systems developed to perform such measurements in highly dynamic environments have the potential to radically reduce downtime associated with lengthy and costly maintenance operations. In addition, they may offer the capability of both earlier and more quantitative identification of deterioration and damage. Therefore, results of this research are expected to benefit the U.S economy and society as it targets major improvements in manufacturing, monitoring and analysis methods with applications in urban systems, sustainability and resiliency of infrastructure. The broader impact of this research focuses in enhancing the efforts for cross-cutting progress in restoration and improvement of urban infrastructure. In this context of civic engagement, the research will leverage resources within the PIs' institution co-operative educational program to transfer related knowledge in educational curricula and train the next generation of engineers working in the area of system diagnostics.

Multimodal remote sensing instrumentation platform coupled with scalable manufacturing and autonomous aerial vehicles will create a framework to rapidly assess the condition of infrastructure systems. Three research objectives in this project are targeted: the use of novel manufacturing procedures in a context of a materials-by-design and advances in metamaterials for the creation of unprecedented opportunities for scalable, tunable, multimodal, multispectral and embedded coatings for automated inspection and deformation quantification; the use of unmanned aerial systems equipped with multi-spectral sensors capable to measure deformation through interrogation of the coatings; the development of methodologies to combine multispectral image point clouds, as well as other sources of information with multiscale and multimodal modeling for state awareness and remaining useful life predictions. Specifically, novel manufacturing procedures will be adopted to design surface coatings and embed them in structural components. The properties of the coatings will be tailored to guarantee their rapid detection by multispectral sensing capturing ultraviolet and infrared radiation as well as visible light. The relative position of the coating elements will be tracked using dedicated algorithms based on computer vision and photogrammetry used to quantify local and global position coordinates of the monitored structures.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project was initially inspired by the need to adopt the Digital Image Correlation (DIC) on a variety of applications at the structural scale. DIC is a non-contact, optical metrology method which has been increasingly used in the past years because it performs reliable and repeatable full field deformation measurements across length and time scales. The method can be deployed also to monitor components through robotic platforms such as drones. In DIC images of patterns on the surface of the tested components are recorded over time. The images are then post-processed to produce deformation measurements. Unfortunately, this approach relies heavily on the quality of the pattern that is deposited or that is naturally present on the inspected component. Commonly this pattern is achieved by spray painting and air brushing which cannot, in general, provide repeatability and consequently limit the robustness and reliability of the DIC results.

A methodology to develop a speckle pattern (coating) designed to accomplish the imaging and adapt to the experimental conditions of a variety of systems was sought in this project. Several research objectives were defined:

  • The use of novel manufacturing procedures and advances in metamaterials for the creation of unprecedented opportunities for scalable, tunable, multimodal, multispectral and embedded coatings for automated inspection and deformation quantification;
  • The use of Unmanned Aerial Vehicles (UAVs) equipped with multi-spectral sensors able to measure deformation through interrogation of the coatings described;
  • The development of robust methodologies to combine multispectral image point clouds, as well as other sources of information (e.g. from applied loads and environment, geometry and material data) with multiscale and multimodal modeling for state awareness and remaining useful life predictions.

A novel bio-inspired speckle pattern development technique was introduced, leveraging spatial imaging parameters in addition to frequency characteristics of speckle patterns, that helped to enhance the results obtained through DIC. Specifically, to address common issues associated with applying speckle patterns for full field deformation measurements using the DIC method, spatial and frequency-based analysis of high quality DIC patterns was performed to extract technical characteristics that determine the overall quality of such patterns for DIC measurements. It was found based on quality analysis of a bio-template pattern that its frequency spectrum properties including its magnitude and phase could be leveraged to numerically create point clouds of a given pixel diameter and with spatial properties controlled by a Gaussian-type power spectrum with adjustable spread, scaling and noise. To evaluate the performance of the generated speckle patterns with this approach a numerical validation approach was considered which showed reduced total bias errors to other patterns. Furthermore, physical experiments of capturing these patterns at different working distances from the imaging system showed the scalability of this optimized pattern and its consistency in the upper bound of RMSE errors.

The generated DIC patterns were demonstrated on applications at different scales, from the micro scale all the way to the structural level scale needed in civil engineering applications. The researchers also focused their attention on the use of unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs), which could accommodate payloads that take advantage of multispectral sensors such as visual cameras (RGB) as well as infrared (IR) imaging which could be subsequently used to apply the DIC method. Beyond deformation measurements, an application of aerial imaging demonstrated how automated rust detection on real bridges can be achieved by fusing RGB and IR images of the structural members, which has critical implications in the periodic assessment of such crucial civil infrastructures.

To leverage experimental results such as deformation measurements from DIC and adopt them in decision making frameworks needed for remaining useful life predictions of components or structures, such measurements are often adopted to calibrate sophisticated digital models for instance finite element models of the component/object/structure of interest. The model is updated through optimization techniques which ensure that its behavior closely resembles the behavior of the actual component. Such approach was recently adopted to estimate the remaining prestress in bridge posttensioned reinforced concrete girders where the knowledge of the stress in the steel tendons embedded in the concrete is needed to estimate the safety factor of the structure.
